revision.text:
{{infobox book | name=Road to Survival | image = Road to Survival.jpg | author=[[William Vogt]] | country=United States | isbn=0548385165 | pub_date=August 5, 1948 }}
'''''Road to Survival''''' is a 1948 book by [[William Vogt]]. It was a major inspiration for the modern [[environmentalist]] movement.
==Summary==
''Road to Survival'' is a summary of the ecological status of the world. Vogt attacks capitalism, and describes [[United States]] history as a "march of destruction".<ref name="Mann">{{cite book|last1=Mann|first1=Charles|title=The Wizard and the Prophet: Two Remarkable Scientists and Their Dueling Visions to Shape Tomorrow's World|date=2018|publisher=Knopf|isbn=0307961699}}</ref>
The book is filled with scientific data, and its world-wide scope was unusual at the time.<ref name="Antioch">{{cite journal|last1=Hunt|first1=Kenneth|title=Road to Survival|journal=The Antioch Review|date=1948|volume=8|issue=4|pages=505-507|doi=10.2307/4609306}}</ref> Ultimately, the book advocates population control as the only way to prevent environmental disaster.<ref>{{cite web|title=ROAD TO SURVIVAL by William Vogt {{!}} Kirkus Reviews|url=https://www.kirkusreviews.com/book-reviews/william-vogt/road-to-survival/|website=Kirkus Reviews|accessdate=25 February 2018|language=en-us}}</ref> Human population could not exceed the planet's [[carrying capacity]] without disaster.<ref name="Mann" />
==Reception== The book was commercially successful. A condensed version was published in ''[[Reader's Digest]]'', and many universities used the book as a textbook. However, his message was attacked by ideologues of all varieties, by [[Conservatism in the United States|conservatives]] for opposing [[capitalism]] and supporting [[birth control]], and by [[Modern liberalism in the United States|liberals]] as proof of "science's bankruptcy in the face of pressing modern problems".<ref name="Mann" />
Later on, the book would inspire the modern [[environmentalism|environmental movement]], with both [[Rachel Carson]] and [[Paul R. Ehrlich|Paul Ehrlich]] being inspired by it.<ref name="Mann" />
==See also== * ''[[Our Plundered Planet]]''
==References==
{{reflist}}
{{Portal bar|Environment|Books}}
[[Category:Environmental non-fiction books]] [[Category:1948 books]] [[Category:1948 in the environment]]

revision.text:
'''SMART''': SCOTLAND is a high profile innovation support grant scheme in Scotland aimed at small and medium-sized firms. It supports commercially viable projects which represent a significant technological advance for the UK sector or industry concerned.
The SMART grant supports technology development through:
* Technical and Commercial [[Feasibility Study|Feasibility Studies]]. These should involve early stage [[R&D]], the outcome of which will enable informed decisions on the technical and commercial feasibility of a new [[Product (business)|product]] or [[Business process|process]]. * Research and Development Projects that aim to develop a pre-production prototype of a new product or process.
==Criteria== Applicants must be based in [[Scotland]] or planning to set up in Scotland and must meet the [[European Community]] definition of a small and medium-sized enterprise which in summary means they must:
* have less than 250 employees (full-time equivalent world-wide, including partners and executive directors) and have either * an annual [[Revenue|turnover]] not exceeding EUR 50 million and/or * an annual balance sheet total not exceeding EUR 43 million.
Awards are judged according to technological, intellectual property, financial and commercial aspects of the application as well as the management expertise available to the business. In addition other aspects such as the project's implications on society such as environmental impact, [[sustainability]] and [[health and safety]] may be taken into account.
==History==
The grant was launched in Scotland as SMART in 1999 and by April 2007 grants had been given to almost 400 businesses across Scotland amounting to some £14.7 million funding.[http://www.scotland.gov.uk/News/Releases/2006/01/26121910] In April 2007 SMART was relaunched [http://www.ettc.co.uk/news/detail.asp?newsid=4354] as the "SMART:SCOTLAND" Programme .
==See also== * [[Innovation]] * [[Scottish Government]] * [[Scottish Executive Enterprise, Transport and Lifelong Learning Department]] * [[Economy of Scotland]] * [[SMART (Northern Irish Business Grant)]]
==External links== * [http://www.scottishbusinessgrants.gov.uk/ Scottish Executive SMART:Scotland] * [http://thescotsman.scotsman.com/business.cfm?id=478512007 Scotsman Paper article] * [http://www.scottishexecutive.gov.uk/Publications/2004/05/19368/37327 Scottish Executive] * [http://www.businesslink.gov.uk/bdotg/action/detail?type=RESOURCES&itemId=1074469930 DTI advice on R&D grants] *[http://www.dti.gov.uk/innovation/index.html Welcome to the DTI's Innovation Home Page]
[[Category:Credit]] [[Category:Business in Scotland]] [[Category:1999 establishments in Scotland]] [[Category:Research and development]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox book | name = The Canon: A Whirligig Tour of the Beautiful Basics of Science | title_orig = | translator = | image = The Canon.jpg | caption = | author = [[Natalie Angier]] | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = | language = English | series = | subject = | genre = | publisher = [[Houghton Mifflin]] / [[Mariner Books]] | release_date = 2007 / 2008 | english_release_date = | media_type = Hardcover / Paperback | pages = | isbn = 978-0-618-24295-5 | dewey= | congress= Q162 .A59 2007 | oclc= | preceded_by = Woman: An Intimate Geography }}
'''''The Canon: A Whirligig Tour of the Beautiful Basics of Science''''' is a book written by American science author [[Natalie Angier]].
==Overview==
''The Canon'' presents a summary of some of the different areas of science, as well as extensive descriptions of, and interviews with, contemporary scientists who work in these fields. Angier’s tenet is that an understanding of the basics of major areas of science can assist with providing a means by which to understand current scientific issues, and that this process should be fun. In her Introduction, Angier writes:
{{quote|Of course you should know about science, for the same reason Dr. Seuss counsels his readers to sing with a Ying or play Ring the Gack: These things are fun, and fun is good.}}
Angier included quotes from the scientists she interviewed throughout her descriptions of different scientific topics in an attempt to show how scientists experience and think about their work, and why they do it.
==Scientists interviewed== To obtain material for ''The Canon'', Angier interviewed a number of scientists, professors, and other science professionals, and incorporated their stories and quotes into her work. She asked them questions such as, "What does it mean to think scientifically?" and "What should nonspecialist nonchildren know about science, and how should they know it, and what is this thing called fun?" Most of these scientists are presently active in their field of research. In addition, many of these scientists have extensive bodies of work listed in detail elsewhere. The below list links the science professionals who Angier interviewed for ''The Canon'' with additional details relating to their work:
*[[Peter Atkins]], a professor of [[chemistry]] at [[Oxford University]] *[[John Bahcall]] (now deceased), an [[astrophysicist]] at [[Princeton University]] *Neta Bahcall, an astrophysicist at Princeton University *[[David Baltimore]], a [[Nobel laureate]] and former president of [[Caltech]] *[[Jacqueline Barton]], a chemistry professor at the [[California Institute of Technology]] *[[Bonnie Bassler]], a [[molecular biologist]] at Princeton University *David Bercovici, a professor of [[geophysics]] at [[Yale University]] *William Blair, a professor of [[astronomy]] at [[Johns Hopkins]] *[[Gunter Blobel]], a Nobel laureate and [[cell biologist]] at [[Rockefeller University]] *[[David Botstein]], a [[geneticist]] at Princeton University *[[Michael E. Brown]], a [[planetary scientist]] at [[Caltech]] *[[Susan Carey]], a professor of [[cognitive neuroscience]] at [[Harvard]] * Rick Danheiser, a chemistry professor at [[MIT]] *Frank DiSalvo, s professor of chemistry at [[Cornell University]] *[[Michael Duff (physicist)|Michael Duff]], a [[theoretical physicist]] formerly at the [[University of Michigan]] *[[Tom Eisner]], a professor of [[chemical ecology]] at Cornell *Andy Feinberg, a geneticist at [[Johns Hopkins University]] *[[Alvan Feinstein]] (now deceased), a professor of [[medicine]] and [[epidemiology]] at the [[Yale University School of Medicine]] *[[Alex Filippenko]], an [[astronomer]] at the [[University of California, Berkeley]] *Gerald Fink, a [[biologist]] at MIT *[[Scott E. Fraser]], a [[bioengineer]] at Caltech * Bob Full, a [[materials scientist]] at the [[University of California, Berkeley]] *[[Peter Galison]], a professor of [[history of physics]] at [[Harvard University]] *[[Brian Greene]], [[theoretical physicist]] at [[Columbia University]] *[[Alan Guth]], a [[physicist]] at MIT *[[Susan Hockfield]], a [[neuroscientist]] and president of MIT * Kip Hodges, director of the School of Earth and Space Exploration at [[Arizona State University]] *[[Roald Hoffmann]], a chemist and poet-playwright at [[Cornell University]] *[[Robert Jaffe]], a physicist at MIT *[[Lucy Jones]], a [[seismologist]] at the [[California Institute of Technology]] * Darcy Kelley, a [[neuroscientist]] at [[Columbia University]] *[[Mary B. Kennedy]], a neurobiologist at [[Caltech]] *[[Andrew Knoll]], a professor of [[natural history]] at [[Harvard]]'s Earth and Planetary Sciences Department *Jonathan Koehler, a professor of [[economics]] at the [[University of Texas]] *[[Walter Lewin]], a professor of physics at MIT *[[Susan Lindquist]], a [[cell biologist]] and former director of the [[Whitehead Institute]] *Stephen Lippard, a professor of chemistry at MIT *Cindy Lustig, a professor of [[psychology]] at the [[University of Michigan]] *[[Tom Maniatis]], a biologist at Harvard University * Mario Mateo, a professor of [[astronomy]] at the University of Michigan *Robert Mathieu, a professor of astronomy at the [[University of Wisconsin]] *Stephen Mayo, a biology professor at Caltech *[[Elliot Meyerowitz]], a biologist at Caltech *[[Kenneth R. Miller]] a biology professor at [[Brown University]] *James L. Mills, chief of the pediatric [[epidemiology]] section of the [[National Institute of Child Health and Human Development]] *[[Daniel Nocera]], a chemist at MIT * Deborah Nolan, a [[statistics]] professor at the [[University of California, Berkeley]] *Michael Novacek, a [[paleontologist]] and [[curator]] at the [[American Museum of Natural History]] * [[John Allen Paulos]], a [[mathematician]] at [[Temple University]] * Sir [[Richard Peto]], an epidemiologist at the [[University of Oxford]] * Steven Pollock, a physics professor at the [[University of Colorado at Boulder|University of Colorado]] *Kent Redford, a biologist with the [[Wildlife Conservation Society]] * Gene Robinson, a [[neuroethologist]] at the [[University of Illinois in Urbana-Champaign]] *Michael Rubner, a materials scientist at MIT * [[Donald Sadoway]], a materials chemistry professor at MIT * [[Maarten Schmidt]], an astrophysicist * [[John Henry Schwarz]], a [[theoretical physicist]] at Caltech * [[Ramamurti Shankar]], a physics professor at [[Princeton University]] * [[Neil Shubin]], a [[paleontologist]] at the [[University of Chicago]] * Chuck Steidel, an astronomy professor at Caltech * Paul Sternberg, a [[developmental biologist]] at Caltech * [[David J. Stevenson]], a [[planetary scientist]] at Caltech * [[Scott Strobel]], a [[biochemist]] at [[Yale University]] * [[Raman Sundrum]], a professor of physics and astronomy at [[Johns Hopkins]] * David Wake, a biologist at the University of California's [[Museum of Vertebrate Zoology]] * Bess Ward, a [[geosciences]] professor at [[Princeton University]] * [[Steven Weinberg]], a [[Nobel laureate]] and [[physics]] professor at the [[University of Texas]] * [[Tim D. White]], a [[paleoanthropologist]] at the [[University of California, Berkeley]] * [[Michael Wigler]], a [[biomedical]] researcher at the [[Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory]] * Cynthia Wolberger, a [[biophysics]] professor at Johns Hopkins University
==External links== *[http://www.natalieangier.com/ Natalie Angier web site] *[http://www.pointofinquiry.org/natalie_angier_the_canon/ Interview] on ''[[Point of Inquiry]]'' podcast, June 29, 2007 *[https://www.nytimes.com/2007/05/27/books/review/Pinker-t.html/ ''New York Times'' Book Review] by [[Steven Pinker]], May 27, 2007 *[https://www.c-span.org/video/?198438-1/canon-whirligig-tour-beautiful-basics-science Presentation by Angier on ''The Canon'', May 24, 2007], [[C-SPAN]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=September 2017}} {{Infobox television | show_name = The Magic School Bus Rides Again | image = The Magic School Bus Rides Again.jpg | genre = [[Adventure film|Adventure]], [[Children's television|Children's]], [[Educational]] | based_on = {{based on|''[[The Magic School Bus]]''|[[Joanna Cole (author)|Joanna Cole]]
[[Bruce Degen]]}} | voices = {{Plainlist| * [[Kate McKinnon]] * [[Lily Tomlin]] }} | theme_music_composer = [[Peter Lurye]] | opentheme = "Ride on the Magic School Bus", performed by [[Lin-Manuel Miranda]] | country = United States
Canada | language = English | num_seasons = 2 | num_episodes = 26 | list_episodes = The Magic School Bus Rides Again#Episodes | runtime = 25 minutes | company = [[Scholastic Corporation|Scholastic Entertainment]]
[[9 Story Media Group]] | distributor = Netflix
9 Story Media Group | network = [[Netflix]] | picture_format = | audio_format = | preceded_by = ''[[The Magic School Bus (TV series)|The Magic School Bus]]'' | first_aired = September 29, 2017 | last_aired = present }} '''''The Magic School Bus Rides Again''''' is a Canadian-American [[animated series|animated]] [[children's television series]], based on [[The Magic School Bus|the book series of the same name]] by [[Joanna Cole (author)|Joanna Cole]] and [[Bruce Degen]]. It also serves as a continuation of the 1994–97 [[PBS Kids]] series ''[[The Magic School Bus (TV series)|The Magic School Bus]]'', with [[Lily Tomlin]] reprising her role as Ms. Frizzle. The series premiered on [[Netflix]] on September 29, 2017.{{Cite news|url=http://ew.com/tv/2017/08/23/new-to-netflix-september-2017/|title=New to Netflix in September: 'Pulp Fiction', 'Jerry Before Seinfeld' and More|date=2017-08-23|work=EW.com|access-date=2017-08-23|language=en-US}} The second season premiered on April 13, 2018. ==Plot== In a sequel to the original 1994–97 series, Valerie Frizzle retires from teaching and passes the keys of the Magic School Bus over to her younger sister, Fiona Frizzle, to embark on new adventures with her class. As they journey on their exciting new field-trips, they discover new locations, creatures, time periods and more to learn about the wonders of science, educating young viewers along the way. ==Voice cast== {{main|List of The Magic School Bus characters}} * [[Kate McKinnon]] as Miss Fiona Felicity Frizzle{{Cite tweet |user=netflix |number=905083345289093120 |date=5 September 2017 |title=The bus is magic. The science is real.}} video, Valerie: "Class, please welcome Miss Fiona Felicity Frizzle". * [[Lily Tomlin]] as Professor Valerie Felicity Frizzle, Ph. D. * Miles Koseleci-Vieira as Arnold Perlstein * Lynsey Pham as Wanda Li * Mikaela Blake as Keesha Franklin * Gabby Clarke as Dorothy Ann Rourke{{cite web|url=http://www.dacostatalent.com/ |title=da Costa Talent |publisher=da Costa Talent |date= |accessdate=2018-01-31}} * Leke Maceda-Rustecki as Carlos Ramon{{cite web|url=http://www.dacostatalent.com/ |title=da Costa Talent |publisher=da Costa Talent |date= |accessdate=2018-01-31}} * Matthew Mintz as Ralphie Tennelli * Birva Pandya as Jyoti Kaur * Kaden Stephen as Tim ===Guest Stars=== ====Season 1==== * [[Will Arnett]] as Galapagos Gil (Frizzle of the Future) * [[Mae Jemison]] as Kathy K. Kuiper (Space Mission: Selfie) * [[Sandra Oh]] as Dr. Sarah Bellum (Ralphie Strikes a Nerve) ====Season 2==== * [[Jay Baruchel]] as Dr. Tillage (Ghost Farm) * [[Nathan Fillion]] as Axle ValveStuck (Waste Not, Want Not) * [[Catherine O'Hara]] as Aunt Tennelli, Teresina Tennelli (Ralphie and the Flying Tennellis) * [[Martin Short]] as Tony Tennelli (Ralphie and the Flying Tennellis) ===Additional Voices=== * Lilly Bartlam * Amos Crawley * Annelise Forbes as Janet Perlstein{{cite web|author=Annelise Forbes |url=https://twitter.com/annelisekfor/status/913775348059377665 |title=Annelise Forbes on Twitter: "I'm playing "Janet" on the new Magic School Bus. @Lin_Manuel sings the theme song and it's a super fun show! @netflix #animation #voiceactor… |publisher=Twitter.com|accessdate=2018-01-31}} * [[Lisa Yamanaka|Lisa Jai]] * [[Julie Lemieux]] * Ana Sani * [[Stuart Stone]] * Jamie Watson * Marcus Craig * Martin Roach * Kevin Vidal ==Episodes== ===Season 1 (2017)=== {{Episode table |background=#990404 |overall= |season= |title= |aux1= |director= |writer= |airdate= |aux1T=Topic |released=y |episodes= {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 1 | EpisodeNumber2 = 1 | Title = Frizzle of the Future | Aux1= Ecosystem | DirectedBy = Richard Weston | WrittenBy = John May & Suzanne Bolch | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2017|9|29}} | ShortSummary = It's a new year in Walkerville Elementary as a brand new teacher arrives to make field trips more fun. However, Arnold is nervous that the new teacher, Ms. Frizzle's Sister, will alter the class ecosystem. | LineColor = 990404 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 2 | EpisodeNumber2 = 2 | Title = Pigs in the Wind | Aux1=Engineering | DirectedBy = Richard Weston | WrittenBy = Mike McPhaden | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2017|9|29}} | ShortSummary = | LineColor = 990404 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 3 | EpisodeNumber2 = 3 | Title = In the Swim | Aux1=Fish Adaptations | DirectedBy = Richard Weston | WrittenBy = John May & Suzanne Bolch | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2017|9|29}} | ShortSummary = | LineColor = 990404 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 4 | EpisodeNumber2 = 4 | Title = The Battle for Rock Mountain | Aux1=Rock Cycle (Rock Layers/Fossils & Erosion) | DirectedBy = Richard Weston | WrittenBy = John May & Suzanne Bolch | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2017|9|29}} | ShortSummary = | LineColor = 990404 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 5 | EpisodeNumber2 = 5 | Title = The Magnetic Mambo | Aux1=Magnetism | DirectedBy = Richard Weston | WrittenBy = Jennifer Daley | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2017|9|29}} | ShortSummary = | LineColor = 990404 }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 6 | EpisodeNumber2 = 6 | Title = Carlos Gets the Sneezes | Aux1=Allergies | DirectedBy = Richard Weston | WrittenBy = George Arthur Bloom | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2017|9|29}} | ShortSummary = In a throwback to "Inside Ralphie", Carlos brings a rat as the class pet, but then he starts sneezing uncontrollably. date|2018|4|13}} | ShortSummary = | LineColor = #4B0082 }} }} ==Production== In 2014, the series was first announced by [[Netflix]] and Scholastic Media, and was entitled ''The Magic School Bus 360°''.{{cite web|url=http://www.comingsoon.net/news/tvnews.php?id=119412|title=Scholastic is Bringing The Magic School Bus 360 degrees to Netflix|publisher=''Coming Soon''|date=June 11, 2014|accessdate=June 11, 2014}} The new iteration of the franchise features a modernized "Ms. Frizzle" (replacing Valerie with her younger sister Fiona) and a high-tech bus that stresses modern inventions such as robotics, wearables and camera technology. The hope is to captivate children's imaginations and motivate their interest in the sciences.{{cite news|url=http://blog.bcdb.com/animated-series-reboots-7699/|title=Three New Animated Series, Reboots All|first=Dave|last=Koch|publisher=Big Cartoon News|date=June 18, 2014|accessdate=June 18, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20140620233051/http://blog.bcdb.com/animated-series-reboots-7699/|archivedate=June 20, 2014|df=mdy-all}} It was produced by [[9 Story Media Group]].{{cite web|url=http://miscrave.com/articles/magic-school-bus-360-delayed/|title=The Magic School Bus 360 delayed to 2017|publisher=''Coming Soon''|date=December 3, 2016|accessdate=December 3, 2016}} Producer [[Stuart Stone]], who voiced Ralphie in the original series, stated that ''The Magic School Bus 360°'' will feature some of the original voice actors in different roles. The show's voice cast is based in [[Los Angeles]], [[California]], [[United States]] and [[Toronto]], [[Ontario]], [[Canada]] with [[Susan Blu]] as the Los Angeles voice director and [[Alyson Court]] as the Toronto voice director.{{cite web|url=https://www.cnet.com/news/magic-school-bus-reboot-netflix-tmz|title=Celebrity cameos, familiar voices to ride 'Magic School Bus' reboot|author=Gael Fashingbauer Cooper|publisher=CNET|date=2017-01-04|accessdate=2017-07-27}} In February 2017, Netflix announced that [[Kate McKinnon]] was cast in the role of Ms. Frizzle (without clarifying it was Fiona, the younger sister of Valerie, now Professor Frizzle, still voiced by Tomlin). The series then changed its name to ''The Magic School Bus Rides Again''.{{cite web |url=http://ew.com/tv/2017/02/08/kate-mckinnon-ms-frizzle-magic-school-bus-netflix/ |title=Kate McKinnon to voice Ms. Frizzle in Netflix's 'Magic School Bus' revival |first=Nivea |last=Serrao |publisher=Entertainment Weekly |date=2017-02-09 |accessdate=2017-07-27 |quote=Netflix has found its Ms. Frizzle! Kate McKinnon (Saturday Night Live, Ghostbusters) will be voicing the beloved animated teacher in the Magic School Bus reboot}} [[Lin-Manuel Miranda]] of ''[[Hamilton (musical)|Hamilton]]'' sings the theme song.{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/lin-manuel-miranda-magic-school-bus-theme-song-1035172|title=Lin-Manuel Miranda Updates 'Magic School Bus' Theme Song for Netflix Reboot|first=Kate|last=Stanhope|website=The Hollywood Reporter|date=September 5, 2017|accessdate=September 5, 2017}} Phoebe Terese, a character from the original series, is replaced by a new student named Jyoti, as it was revealed that Phoebe transferred back to her old school.{{Cite news|url=https://www.dailydot.com/parsec/magic-school-bus-rides-again-review/|title=‘The Magic School Bus Rides Again’ brings new magic to a familiar set of wheels|date=2017-09-29|work=Dailydot.com|access-date=2017-09-30|language=en-US}}{{cite episode|title=Frizzle of the Future|credits=Writers: May, John & Bolch, Suzanne Director: Weston, Richard|series=The Magic School Bus Rides Again|network=Netflix|airdate=September 29, 2017|season=1|number=1}} The series was released on [[Netflix]] on September 29, 2017. The second season was released on April 13, 2018 in association with [[Nelvana]], which also worked on the original series.{{Cite news|url=http://ew.com/tv/2018/03/20/coming-to-netflix-in-april/|title=Scarface, The Iron Giant, Seven coming to Netflix in April|date=2018-03-21|work=EW.com|access-date=2018-03-21|language=en-US}} The show is Flash animated unlike the original series that is traditionally-animated. Despite its second season made with Nelvana, the entire Flash-animated show is made with Adobe After Effects, Adobe Animate (formerly Adobe Flash) and Adobe Photoshop. ==References== {{Reflist}}
